Pour M, Lloyd george* You3 aye2 eortaineraent rccu comme moi lo long tolcgrammo do Soli, date da 18 jlovombro, *B uno heure, demandant des inodJ.ficatj.on aux conditions do Isarmistice0 La pluport do colles-ci somblont do nata.ro purement militaire ou navale qui sont da rossort da Haut Gommandement* En GO qui concorno la ravitaillemont do PAllemagno, je suggore que nous invitions le Gouvernemont Ailomand a so reporter a' notre intention, do ju* exprimdo dans le texts do l'f armistice^ de lui fournlr des donr&*eo do ravitail^lement dans la mosure oil nous lo jugorons nooossairoa Hons indiquerions ogalemont quo la condition ossontie.ll.e_ do cotte ^fournituro ost, bien ontendu, la mise a la disposition dos Allies des navires allemands et quo la satisfaction des deraandes du Goirvernement Allomand ne pourra ^5re qu-aceeleree s*il prend a present toutos mosaros utiles pour rnettrc sos . navires a memo do prond.ro la mer et pour recrutor los equipages necessaireSc Jv\estime aussi quo lsAllemagne devrait envoyer des Doleguds a 6pa qui puissent faire connalvtre, justifior et ex- poser un plan de repartition; nous enverrions de notre Coto dos Delegue^s qui fixeraient los conditions dans losquelles les nayires allemands navigueront notamment on co qui concorno le pavilion ot lo complement de leur equipage, Jo vous prie do me fairs connuTtro votre munioro de voir rinsi quo vos propositions au sujet de votro represent?:tion va Spa. CLI2JG3NG3AU.19th November, 1918* From The Prime Minister, To :- Mo Clemenceau, I agree with.you that the majority of Golfs requests formodifications in the conditions of tho armistice are of amilitary or naval character. These are matters for marshal foch and Admiral V/omyss respectively0 I also agree in your general remarks on tho re-victuallingof Germany and more particularly that the essential conditionsof our making tho provision is tho placing of Gorman ships at the ' tho disposal of tho i.lllos*: Tho Admiralty have olroi dysent a communication to Germany advising thorn to preparethoir ships for sea, I am strongly of opinion however that tho negotiations on this hoad should, take place ,not., at Spa but in London, whoreis centred tho whole of the Allied,machinery for dealing withthose questions. The rovictualling of Germany can only boconsidered as pert of tho larger oroblem of rovictualling allthe nations in need of supplies, which include Greece, Serbia,Finland end other original territories of Russia and Austria aswell as France, Italy and the United Kingdoms Tho Committee of Representatives of the Allied Food councils meeting tomorrow and I am asking them and the TransportiSxocutivo Council to discuss the problem of relief and I amsuggesting that they should summon enemy delegates to England, In those circumstances I think that the appropriate replyto Self on the ouestion of rovictualling Germany is that the question is under active consideration and tla.it a further communication will be made in a few days'11 time. If you concur in the above arrangements I propose that a reply to this effectbo sent by the British and French Governments simultancousIjthrough tho prooor diplom: tic channelscjfcitoha.].! Pardons,m S..7.1.November 20th'; 1910,
